title: Decompose a netify object into edge and node data frames ‚Äî decompose_netify
text: list containing two data frames: edge_data: data frame row represents edge columns: : Source node identifier : Target node identifier time: Time period (character; "1" cross-sectional networks) weight: Edge weight values (using original weight variable name specified) Additional columns dyadic variables stored netify object nodal_data: data frame row represents node-time combination columns: name: Node identifier time: Time period (character; "1" cross-sectional networks) Additional columns nodal variables stored netify object

title: Decompose a netify object into edge and node data frames ‚Äî decompose_netify
text: function helpful : Edge data processing: Extracts adjacency matrix (array longitudinal networks) netify object Optionally removes zero-weight edges based remove_zeros parameter Merges dyadic variables stored netify object Renames columns standardized names (, , time) Node data processing: Extracts nodal attributes present, constructs actor_pds information Ensures consistent time variable across node edge data Renames columns standardized names (name, time) Time handling: cross-sectional networks: Sets time "1" data frames longitudinal networks: Preserves original time periods character values ego networks: Extracts time ego-time concatenated identifiers Variable preservation: dyadic nodal variables stored netify object preserved output data frames. Dyadic variables merged edge data, nodal variables remain nodal data frame.

title: Decompose a netify object into edge and node data frames ‚Äî decompose_netify
text: Cassy Dorff, Shahryar Minhas

title: Decompose a netify object into edge and node data frames ‚Äî decompose_netify
code: # Load example data data(icews)  # Example 1: Cross-sectional network icews_10 <- icews[icews$year == 2010, ]  # Create netify object net_cs <- netify(     icews_10,     actor1 = "i", actor2 = "j",     symmetric = FALSE,     weight = "verbCoop" )  # Decompose to data frames decomposed_cs <- decompose_netify(net_cs)  # Examine structure str(decomposed_cs) #> List of 2 #>  $ edge_data :'data.frame':	9976 obs. of  4 variables: #>   ..$ from    : chr [1:9976] "Afghanistan" "Afghanistan" "Afghanistan" "Afghanistan" ... #>   ..$ to      : chr [1:9976] "Argentina" "Armenia" "Australia" "Austria" ... #>   ..$ time    : chr [1:9976] "1" "1" "1" "1" ... #>   ..$ verbCoop: num [1:9976] 1 7 125 1 7 3 14 3 2 16 ... #>  $ nodal_data:'data.frame':	152 obs. of  2 variables: #>   ..$ name: chr [1:152] "Afghanistan" "Albania" "Algeria" "Angola" ... #>   ..$ time: chr [1:152] "1" "1" "1" "1" ... head(decomposed_cs$edge_data) #>          from         to time verbCoop #> 1 Afghanistan  Argentina    1        1 #> 2 Afghanistan    Armenia    1        7 #> 3 Afghanistan  Australia    1      125 #> 4 Afghanistan    Austria    1        1 #> 5 Afghanistan Azerbaijan    1        7 #> 6 Afghanistan    Bahrain    1        3 head(decomposed_cs$nodal_data) #>          name time #> 1 Afghanistan    1 #> 2     Albania    1 #> 3     Algeria    1 #> 4      Angola    1 #> 5   Argentina    1 #> 6     Armenia    1  # Example 2: Longitudinal network with attributes nvars <- c("i_polity2", "i_log_gdp", "i_log_pop") dvars <- c("matlCoop", "verbConf", "matlConf")  net_longit <- netify(     icews,     actor1 = "i", actor2 = "j",     time = "year",     symmetric = FALSE,     weight = "verbCoop",     nodal_vars = nvars,     dyad_vars = dvars )  # Decompose with all attributes decomposed_longit <- decompose_netify(net_longit)  # Check that variables are preserved names(decomposed_longit$edge_data) # Includes dyadic variables #> [1] "from"     "to"       "time"     "verbCoop" "matlCoop" "verbConf" "matlConf" names(decomposed_longit$nodal_data) # Includes nodal variables #> [1] "name"      "time"      "i_polity2" "i_log_gdp" "i_log_pop"  # Example 3: Keep zero-weight edges decomposed_with_zeros <- decompose_netify(net_cs, remove_zeros = FALSE)  # Compare edge counts nrow(decomposed_cs$edge_data) # Without zeros #> [1] 9976 nrow(decomposed_with_zeros$edge_data) # With zeros #> [1] 22952  # Example 4: Use for visualization prep if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Decompose for use with ggplot2 plot_data <- decompose_netify(net_cs)  # Can now use edge_data and nodal_data separately # for network visualization } # }

text: list containing four elements: adj_mat: adjacency matrix extracted network object unipartite networks: Square matrix dimension n√ón bipartite networks: Full square matrix dimension (n‚ÇÅ+n‚ÇÇ)√ó(n‚ÇÅ+n‚ÇÇ) Values edge weights specified, otherwise 0/1 ndata: data frame vertex attributes, NULL none exist Always includes 'actor' column vertex names Additional columns vertex attribute (excluding system attributes) ddata: data frame edge attributes, NULL none exist Columns '' '' specify edge endpoints using vertex names Additional columns edge attribute weight: edge attribute name used weights, provided

title: Decompose a network object into base R components ‚Äî decompose_statnet
text: function handles unipartite bipartite networks appropriately: Network type detection: Bipartite networks identified using .bipartite() bipartite partition size retrieved 'bipartite' network attribute Vertex naming: function checks existing vertex names 'vertex.names' attribute. names just default numeric sequence (1, 2, 3, ...), treated missing. Default names assigned needed: Unipartite networks: "a1", "a2", ..., "" Bipartite networks: "r1", "r2", ... first partition; "c1", "c2", ... second partition Matrix extraction: Unlike igraph's bipartite handling, network package returns full adjacency matrix even bipartite networks. function: Extracts full matrix using .matrix.network.adjacency() bipartite networks, matrix dimension (n‚ÇÅ+n‚ÇÇ)√ó(n‚ÇÅ+n‚ÇÇ) first n‚ÇÅ rows/columns first partition Attribute handling: System attributes ('vertex.names' 'na') excluded vertex attribute data frame. user-defined vertex edge attributes preserved.

title: Decompose a network object into base R components ‚Äî decompose_statnet
text: longitudinal networks changing actor composition, explicitly set vertex names decomposition ensure consistent actor identification across time periods. adjacency matrix format differs function decompose_igraph bipartite networks: function returns full square matrix decompose_igraph returns rectangular bipartite portion. Edge directions preserved adjacency matrix according network's directed/undirected property.

text: netlet netify object containing network data. dyad_vars Character vector dyadic attribute names analyze. NULL, analyzes available dyadic variables. edge_vars Character vector edge variables correlate . NULL, uses main network matrix. method Character string specifying correlation method: "pearson" Pearson product-moment correlation (default) "spearman" Spearman rank correlation "kendall" Kendall's tau correlation binary_network Logical. title: Create ego-centric layouts for ego networks ‚Äî ego_layouts
text: list data frames x,y coordinates time period

title: Create ego-centric layouts for ego networks ‚Äî ego_layouts
text: Three layout algorithms provided: Hierarchical Layout: Places ego center arranges alters concentric circles based network centrality. central alters placed closer ego. Radial Layout: Places ego center arranges alters concentric rings based connection strength quartiles. Stronger connections placed inner rings. Ego Centric Layout: Uses force-directed layout ensures ego remains center buffer zone. Preserves natural clustering maintaining ego visibility.

title: Create ego network from a netify object ‚Äî ego_netify

title: Create ego network from a netify object ‚Äî ego_netify
text: netlet netify object (class "netify") extract ego network. ego Character string specifying name ego create ego network. Must match actor name netify object. threshold Numeric value vector specifying threshold including alters ego network based edge weights. longitudinal networks, can vector length equal number time periods apply different thresholds time. NULL (default), uses 0 unweighted networks mean edge weight weighted networks. ngbd_direction Character string specifying neighbors include directed networks. Options : "": Include alters ego outgoing ties "": Include alters ego incoming ties "": Include alters tie /ego (default) include_ego Logical. TRUE (default), ego node included ego network. FALSE, alters included.

title: Create ego network from a netify object ‚Äî ego_netify
text: function extracts ego network identifying nodes connected specified ego based given criteria: Neighborhood definition: unweighted networks: nodes edges /ego (threshold = 0) weighted networks: nodes edge weights exceeding threshold Direction matters directed networks (controlled ngbd_direction) Threshold behavior: specified, defaults 0 unweighted networks specified weighted networks, uses mean edge weight longitudinal networks, can vary time period vector provided Edges weights > threshold included (‚â•) Output structure: function preserves attributes original netify object, including nodal dyadic variables, subsets include ego neighbors. longitudinal networks, ego networks may vary composition across time periods relationships change. Limitations: Currently support multilayer networks Currently support bipartite networks

title: Generate symmetric identifiers for dyadic data ‚Äî gen_symm_id

title: Generate symmetric identifiers for dyadic data ‚Äî gen_symm_id
text: function ensures symmetry alphabetically sorting actor names creating identifier. guarantees : dyad "USA-China" receives ID "China-USA" dyad "Brazil-Argentina" receives ID "Argentina-Brazil" Actor pairs consistently ordered regardless input order time column specified, appended symmetric ID maintain unique identifiers across different time periods. allows proper aggregation longitudinal dyadic data preserving temporal variation.

title: Generate symmetric identifiers for dyadic data ‚Äî gen_symm_id
text: actor values converted character strings creating IDs ensure consistent sorting behavior across different data types. underscore character ("_") used separator IDs. actor names contain underscores, IDs still unique may harder parse visually. function primarily used internally aggregate_dyad efficient symmetric aggregation, can used independently creating symmetric dyad identifiers.

title: Generate symmetric identifiers for dyadic data ‚Äî gen_symm_id
text: Shahryar Minhas

title: Generate symmetric identifiers for dyadic data ‚Äî gen_symm_id
code: # Create example dyadic data trade_df <- data.frame(     from = c("USA", "China", "Russia", "USA", "Brazil", "Argentina"),     to = c("China", "USA", "USA", "Russia", "Argentina", "Brazil"),     trade_value = c(100, 100, 50, 75, 30, 25),     year = c(2020, 2020, 2021, 2021, 2021, 2021) )  # Generate symmetric IDs without time trade_df$symm_id <- gen_symm_id(trade_df, "from", "to") print(trade_df[, c("from", "to", "symm_id")]) #>        from        to          symm_id #> 1       USA     China        China_USA #> 2     China       USA        China_USA #> 3    Russia       USA       Russia_USA #> 4       USA    Russia       Russia_USA #> 5    Brazil Argentina Argentina_Brazil #> 6 Argentina    Brazil Argentina_Brazil # Note: USA-China and China-USA both get "China_USA"  # Generate symmetric IDs with time trade_df$symm_id_time <- gen_symm_id(trade_df, "from", "to", "year") print(trade_df[, c("from", "to", "year", "symm_id_time")]) #>        from        to year          symm_id_time #> 1       USA     China 2020        China_USA_2020 #> 2     China       USA 2020        China_USA_2020 #> 3    Russia       USA 2021       Russia_USA_2021 #> 4       USA    Russia 2021       Russia_USA_2021 #> 5    Brazil Argentina 2021 Argentina_Brazil_2021 #> 6 Argentina    Brazil 2021 Argentina_Brazil_2021 # Note: USA-China in 2020 gets "China_USA_2020"  # Use for aggregation of undirected relationships trade_df$total_trade <- ave(     trade_df$trade_value,     trade_df$symm_id_time,     FUN = sum ) print(unique(trade_df[, c("symm_id_time", "total_trade")])) #>            symm_id_time total_trade #> 1        China_USA_2020         200 #> 3       Russia_USA_2021         125 #> 5 Argentina_Brazil_2021          55  # Example with longitudinal data library(netify) data(icews) icews_sample <- icews[1:100, ]  # Create symmetric IDs for conflict events icews_sample$symm_dyad <- gen_symm_id(     icews_sample,     actor1 = "i",     actor2 = "j",     time = "year" )  # Check that symmetric pairs get same ID icews_sample[icews_sample$i == "United States" & icews_sample$j == "Israel", "symm_dyad"] #> character(0) icews_sample[icews_sample$i == "Israel" & icews_sample$j == "United States", "symm_dyad"] #> character(0)

text: dyad_data data.frame containing dyadic observations. coerced data.frame tibble data.table provided. actor1 Character string specifying column name first actor dyad. actor2 Character string specifying column name second actor dyad. symmetric Logical. TRUE (default), treats network undirected (.e., edges direction). FALSE, treats network directed. mode Character string specifying network structure. Options : "unipartite": One set actors (default) "bipartite": Two distinct sets actors weight Character string specifying column name containing edge weights. NULL (default), edges treated unweighted (binary). sum_dyads Logical. TRUE, sums weight values multiple edges exist actor pair. FALSE (default), uses last observed value. diag_to_NA Logical. TRUE (default), sets diagonal values (self-loops) NA. Automatically set FALSE bipartite networks. missing_to_zero Logical. TRUE (default), treats missing edges zeros. FALSE, missing edges remain NA. nodelist Character vector actor names include network. provided, ensures listed actors appear network even edges (isolates). Useful working edgelists contain active dyads.

text: Note usage: function exported available direct use, primary recommended way create netify objects dyadic data netify() function. netify() function: Provides consistent interface cross-sectional longitudinal data Includes additional data validation preprocessing options Can incorporate nodal dyadic attributes creation Offers comprehensive parameter checking Use get_adjacency() directly need simple adjacency matrix creation without additional features.

code: # Load example data data(icews)  # Subset to one year for cross-sectional analysis icews_2010 <- icews[icews$year == 2010, ]  # Create a directed network with verbal cooperation weights verbCoop_net <- get_adjacency(     dyad_data = icews_2010,     actor1 = "i",     actor2 = "j",     symmetric = FALSE,     weight = "verbCoop" )  # Create a directed network with material conflict weights matlConf_net <- get_adjacency(     dyad_data = icews_2010,     actor1 = "i",     actor2 = "j",     symmetric = FALSE,     weight = "matlConf" )  # Verify class class(verbCoop_net) # "netify" #> [1] "netify"  # Check dimensions dim(verbCoop_net) #> [1] 152 152

title: Calculate ego-centric layout positions for network visualization ‚Äî get_ego_layout
code: get_ego_layout(   netlet,   layout = "star",   group_by = NULL,   order_by = NULL,   weight_to_distance = FALSE,   ring_gap = 0.3,   ego_size = 0.1,   seed = 6886 )

title: Calculate ego-centric layout positions for network visualization ‚Äî get_ego_layout
text: netlet netify object (class "netify") ego network, created using ego_netify. object must ego_netify = TRUE attribute. layout Character string specifying ego-centric layout algorithm. Options: "radial": Places ego center alters arranged circle around . Distance center can encode relationship strength. "concentric": Places ego center alters concentric circles based grouping variable relationship strength. "star": Simple star layout ego center alters equally spaced around (default). group_by Character string specifying nodal attribute use grouping alters layout. "radial" layout, groups arranged sectors. "concentric" layout, groups determine ring alters appear . NULL (default), grouping applied. order_by Character string specifying nodal attribute use ordering alters within groups around ego. Common options include network statistics like "degree_total" custom attributes. NULL (default), alters arranged alphabetically. weight_to_distance Logical. TRUE network weighted, use edge weights determine distance ego (higher weights = closer). "radial" layout . Default FALSE. ring_gap Numeric value 0 1 specifying gap concentric rings proportion total radius. used "concentric" layout. Default 0.3. ego_size Numeric value specifying relative size central area reserved ego. Larger values create space ego alters. Default 0.1. seed Integer random number generation ensure reproducible layouts ties ordering. Default 6886.

title: Calculate ego-centric layout positions for network visualization ‚Äî get_ego_layout
text: list data frames (one per time period) data frame contains: index: Integer node index actor: Character string actor name x: Numeric x-coordinate node position y: Numeric y-coordinate node position cross-sectional networks, returns list one element. longitudinal networks, returns named list time periods names.

title: Calculate ego-centric layout positions for network visualization ‚Äî get_ego_layout
text: function provides specialized layouts ego networks emphasize ego-alter structure: Layout algorithms: Radial: Places ego origin arranges alters circle around . grouping specified, alters arranged sectors related nodes near . weight_to_distance TRUE, alters stronger ties ego placed closer center. Concentric: Places ego origin arranges alters concentric circles. ring assignment can based grouping variable (categorical) continuous variable (discretized rings). Star: simple star layout places ego center distributes alters evenly around single circle. equivalent radial layout without grouping weighting. Visual encoding: layouts allow encoding network properties spatial arrangement: Distance ego: Can represent tie strength, frequency interaction, dyadic measures Angular position: Can group similar alters together (e.g., family, friends, colleagues) Ring assignment: Can represent categories, levels importance, discretized continuous variables Longitudinal networks: longitudinal ego networks, function maintains consistent angular positions alters across time periods possible, making easier track changes ego's network time.

title: Calculate ego-centric layout positions for network visualization ‚Äî get_ego_layout

title: Calculate node layout positions for netify visualization ‚Äî get_node_layout
text: netlet netify object (class "netify") compute layout positions. layout Character string specifying layout algorithm use. Options include: "nicely": Automatic selection appropriate layout (default unipartite) "bipartite": Two-column layout bipartite networks (default bipartite) "fruchtermanreingold" "fr": Force-directed layout "kamadakawai" "kk": Another force-directed layout "circle": Nodes arranged circle "star": Star-shaped layout "grid": Nodes grid "tree": Hierarchical tree layout "random" "randomly": Random positions Additional options: "graphopt", "sugiyama", "drl", "lgl", "dh", "gem", "mds" NULL, defaults "nicely" unipartite "bipartite" bipartite networks. static_actor_positions Logical. TRUE, maintains consistent node positions across time periods longitudinal networks. FALSE (default), time period gets optimized layout. which_static Integer specifying time period's layout use static template static_actor_positions TRUE. NULL (default), creates static layout based union edges across time periods, giving weight persistent edges. seed Integer random number generation ensure reproducible layouts. Default 6886. ig_netlet optional pre-converted igraph object. provided, function use directly instead converting netify object . ... Additional arguments passed ego-specific layout functions layout "radial" "concentric". See get_ego_layout available options (ego_group_by, ego_order_by, ego_weight_to_distance, etc.).

title: Calculate node layout positions for netify visualization ‚Äî get_node_layout
text: list data frames (one per time period) data frame contains: index: Integer node index actor: Character string actor name x: Numeric x-coordinate node position y: Numeric y-coordinate node position cross-sectional networks, returns list one element. longitudinal networks, returns named list time periods names.

title: Calculate node layout positions for netify visualization ‚Äî get_node_layout
text: function handles layout generation cross-sectional longitudinal networks several key features: Layout algorithms: function provides access major igraph layout algorithms. default "nicely" option automatically selects appropriate algorithm based network structure. ego networks, specialized layouts ("radial" "concentric") available emphasize ego-alter structure. Longitudinal layouts: longitudinal networks, two approaches available: Dynamic layouts: time period gets optimized layout, may better reveal structural changes makes visual comparison harder Static layouts: time periods use node positions, facilitating visual comparison network evolution using static layouts which_static = NULL, function creates composite layout based union edges across time periods. Edges appear frequently given higher weight, producing layouts emphasize stable core structure network. Bipartite networks: bipartite networks, default layout arranges two node sets separate columns.

what: Analyze homophily in network data ‚Äî homophily
title: Analyze homophily in network data ‚Äî homophily
text: Tests whether connected actors similar attributes (homophily). Calculates correlation attribute similarity tie presence, support multiple similarity metrics significance testing.

title: Analyze homophily in network data ‚Äî homophily
code: homophily(   netlet,   attribute,   method = "correlation",   threshold = 0,   significance_test = TRUE,   n_permutations = 1000,   alpha = 0.05,   other_stats = NULL,   ... )

title: Analyze homophily in network data ‚Äî homophily
text: netlet netify object containing network data. attribute Character string specifying nodal attribute analyze. method Character string specifying similarity metric: "correlation" Negative absolute difference continuous data (default) "euclidean" Negative euclidean distance continuous data "manhattan" Negative Manhattan/city-block distance continuous data "cosine" Cosine similarity continuous data "categorical" Binary similarity (0/1) categorical data "jaccard" Jaccard similarity binary/presence-absence data "hamming" Negative Hamming distance categorical data threshold Numeric value function determine tie presence weighted networks. numeric, edges weights > threshold considered ties. function, take network matrix return logical matrix. Default 0 (positive weight tie). Common values: 0 (default), mean(weights), median(weights), quantile-based thresholds. pre-binarized networks, consider using mutate_weights() first. significance_test Logical. Whether perform permutation test. Default TRUE. n_permutations Number permutations significance testing. Default 1000. alpha Significance level confidence intervals. Default 0.05. other_stats Named list custom functions additional statistics. ... Additional arguments passed custom functions.

title: Analyze homophily in network data ‚Äî homophily
text: Data frame homophily statistics per network/time period: net Network/time identifier layer Layer name attribute Analyzed attribute name method Similarity method used threshold_value Threshold used determining ties (NA binary networks) homophily_correlation Correlation similarity tie presence (binary: tie/tie) mean_similarity_connected Mean similarity among connected pairs (weight > threshold) mean_similarity_unconnected Mean similarity among unconnected pairs (weight <= threshold missing) similarity_difference Difference connected unconnected mean similarities p_value Permutation test p-value ci_lower, ci_upper Confidence interval bounds n_connected_pairs Number connected pairs n_unconnected_pairs Number unconnected pairs

title: Analyze homophily in network data ‚Äî homophily
text: Similarity Metrics: continuous attributes: correlation: Based absolute difference, good general purpose metric euclidean: Similar correlation single attributes manhattan: Less sensitive outliers euclidean cosine: Useful normalized data sign matters categorical/binary attributes: categorical: Simple matching (1 , 0 different) jaccard: binary data, emphasizes shared presence shared absence hamming: Counts positions values differ (negated similarity) Threshold Parameter: weighted networks, threshold parameter determines edge weights constitute "connection". can specify: numeric value: edges weight > threshold ties function: take matrix return single numeric threshold Common threshold functions: function(x) mean(x, na.rm = TRUE) - mean weight function(x) median(x, na.rm = TRUE) - median weight function(x) quantile(x, 0.75, na.rm = TRUE) - 75th percentile complex binarization needs (e.g., different thresholds time period), consider using mutate_weights() pre-process network.

title: Analyze homophily in network data ‚Äî homophily
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Basic homophily analysis with default threshold (> 0) homophily_default <- homophily(net, attribute = "group")  # Using different similarity metrics for continuous data homophily_manhattan <- homophily(     net,     attribute = "age",     method = "manhattan" # Less sensitive to outliers )  # For binary attributes (e.g., gender, membership) homophily_jaccard <- homophily(     net,     attribute = "member",     method = "jaccard" # Better for binary data than correlation )  # For categorical attributes homophily_categorical <- homophily(     net,     attribute = "department",     method = "categorical" )  # Combining method and threshold homophily_combined <- homophily(     net,     attribute = "score",     method = "manhattan",     threshold = function(x) quantile(x, 0.75, na.rm = TRUE) ) } # }

what: Create multilayer networks from multiple netify objects ‚Äî layer_netify
title: Create multilayer networks from multiple netify objects ‚Äî layer_netify
text: layer_netify combines multiple netify objects single multilayer network structure. input network becomes layer resulting multilayer network, enabling analysis multiple relationship types network views simultaneously.

title: Create multilayer networks from multiple netify objects ‚Äî layer_netify
code: layer_netify(netlet_list, layer_labels = NULL)

title: Create multilayer networks from multiple netify objects ‚Äî layer_netify
text: netlet_list list netify objects layer together. objects must compatible dimensions attributes (see Details). layer_labels Character vector specifying names layer. NULL (default), uses names netlet_list generates generic labels ("layer1", "layer2", etc.). Length must match number netify objects.

title: Create multilayer networks from multiple netify objects ‚Äî layer_netify
text: multilayer netify object structure depending input type: Cross-sectional input: 3D array [actors √ó actors √ó layers] Longitudinal array input: 4D array [actors √ó actors √ó layers √ó time] Longitudinal list input: List 3D arrays, one per time period returned object maintains netify class includes: Combined nodal attributes (compatible) Combined dyadic attributes (compatible) Layer information accessible via attr(obj, 'layers') standard netify attributes

title: Create multilayer networks from multiple netify objects ‚Äî layer_netify
text: Compatibility requirements: netify objects netlet_list must identical: Network type (cross-sectional longitudinal) Dimensions (actors time periods) Symmetry (directed undirected) Mode (unipartite bipartite) Actor composition (actors order) Attribute handling: Nodal dyadic attributes combined possible: attributes identical across layers, first layer's attributes used attributes differ compatible structure, merged attributes incompatible, warning issued attributes must added manually using add_node_vars() add_dyad_vars()

title: Create multilayer networks from multiple netify objects ‚Äî layer_netify
text: Memory usage increases number layers. large networks many layers, consider whether layers necessary analysis.

title: Create multilayer networks from multiple netify objects ‚Äî layer_netify
text: Cassy Dorff, Shahryar Minhas

title: Create multilayer networks from multiple netify objects ‚Äî layer_netify
code: # Load example data data(icews)  # Example 1: Cross-sectional multilayer network icews_10 <- icews[icews$year == 2010, ]  # Create separate networks for different interaction types verbal_coop <- netify(     icews_10,     actor1 = "i", actor2 = "j",     symmetric = FALSE,     weight = "verbCoop",     nodal_vars = c("i_log_gdp", "i_log_pop"),     dyad_vars = "verbConf" )  material_coop <- netify(     icews_10,     actor1 = "i", actor2 = "j",     symmetric = FALSE,     weight = "matlCoop",     nodal_vars = "i_polity2",     dyad_vars = "matlConf" )  # Layer them together coop_multilayer <- layer_netify(     netlet_list = list(verbal_coop, material_coop),     layer_labels = c("Verbal", "Material") )  # Check structure dim(get_raw(coop_multilayer)) # [actors √ó actors √ó 2] #> [1] 152 152   2 attr(coop_multilayer, "layers") # "Verbal" "Material" #> [1] "Verbal"   "Material"  # Example 2: Longitudinal multilayer (array format) verbal_longit <- netify(     icews,     actor1 = "i", actor2 = "j", time = "year",     symmetric = FALSE,     weight = "verbCoop",     output_format = "longit_array" )  material_longit <- netify(     icews,     actor1 = "i", actor2 = "j", time = "year",     symmetric = FALSE,     weight = "matlCoop",     output_format = "longit_array" )  # Create longitudinal multilayer longit_multilayer <- layer_netify(     list(verbal_longit, material_longit),     layer_labels = c("Verbal", "Material") )  dim(get_raw(longit_multilayer)) # [actors √ó actors √ó 2 √ó years] #> [1] 152 152   2  13

what: Mutate edge weights in a netify object ‚Äî mutate_weights
title: Mutate edge weights in a netify object ‚Äî mutate_weights
text: mutate_weights applies mathematical transformations edge weights netify object. useful normalizing data, handling skewed distributions, creating binary networks, applying custom mathematical transformation network weights.

title: Mutate edge weights in a netify object ‚Äî mutate_weights
code: mutate_weights(   netlet,   transform_fn = NULL,   add_constant = 0,   new_name = NULL,   keep_original = TRUE )

title: Mutate edge weights in a netify object ‚Äî mutate_weights
text: netlet netify object edge weights transform transform_fn function apply weights. Can function takes matrix returns matrix (e.g., log, sqrt, function(x) x^2). NULL, add_constant operation performed. add_constant Numeric value add weights applying transform_fn. Useful log transformations (e.g., add_constant = 1 log(x + 1)) shifting distributions. new_name Optional new name weight variable. provided, updates weight attribute descriptive labels. NULL, keeps original name. keep_original Logical. TRUE (default), preserves original weights dyadic variable. FALSE, discards original weights save memory.

title: Mutate edge weights in a netify object ‚Äî mutate_weights
text: netify object transformed weights. original weights optionally preserved dyadic variable named "original_weight".

title: Mutate edge weights in a netify object ‚Äî mutate_weights
text: function handles netify object types: Cross-sectional: Transforms single network matrix Longitudinal arrays: Transforms time slice Longitudinal lists: Transforms time period matrix function automatically updates network attributes: Updates weight_binary transformation results 0/1 values Updates detail_weight transformation description Preserves network nodal attributes longitudinal arrays, original weight preservation yet implemented show informational message.

title: Mutate edge weights in a netify object ‚Äî mutate_weights
text: Cassy Dorff, Shahryar Minhas

title: Mutate edge weights in a netify object ‚Äî mutate_weights
code: # Load example data data(icews) icews_2010 <- icews[icews$year == 2010, ]  # Create a weighted network net <- netify(     icews_2010,     actor1 = "i", actor2 = "j",     symmetric = FALSE,     weight = "verbCoop" )  # Example 1: Log transformation (common for skewed data) net_log <- mutate_weights(     net,     transform_fn = log,     add_constant = 1, # log(x + 1) to handle zeros     new_name = "log_verbCoop" ) print(net_log) #> ‚úî Hello, you have created network data, yay! #> ‚Ä¢ Unipartite #> ‚Ä¢ Asymmetric #> ‚Ä¢ log_verbCoop (transformed) #> ‚Ä¢ Cross-Sectional #> ‚Ä¢ # Unique Actors: 152 #> Network Summary Statistics: #>           dens miss  mean recip trans #> verbCoop 0.432    0 0.975 0.966 0.639 #> ‚Ä¢ Nodal Features: None #> ‚Ä¢ Dyad Features: original_weight  # Example 2: Square root transformation (moderate skewness) net_sqrt <- mutate_weights(     net,     transform_fn = sqrt,     new_name = "sqrt_verbCoop" )  # Example 3: Binarization (convert to presence/absence) net_binary <- mutate_weights(     net,     transform_fn = function(x) ifelse(x > 0, 1, 0),     new_name = "verbCoop_binary" ) #> ‚Ñπ network has been binarized through transformation  # Example 4: Standardization (z-scores) net_std <- mutate_weights(     net,     transform_fn = function(x) {         mean_x <- mean(x, na.rm = TRUE)         sd_x <- sd(x, na.rm = TRUE)         return((x - mean_x) / sd_x)     },     new_name = "verbCoop_standardized" )  # Example 5: Rank transformation net_rank <- mutate_weights(     net,     transform_fn = function(x) rank(x, na.last = "keep"),     new_name = "verbCoop_ranked" )  # Example 6: Power transformation net_power <- mutate_weights(     net,     transform_fn = function(x) x^0.5, # Square root as power     new_name = "verbCoop_power" )  # Example 7: Min-max normalization (scale to 0-1) net_norm <- mutate_weights(     net,     transform_fn = function(x) {         min_x <- min(x, na.rm = TRUE)         max_x <- max(x, na.rm = TRUE)         return((x - min_x) / (max_x - min_x))     },     new_name = "verbCoop_normalized" )  # Example 8: Winsorization (cap extreme values) net_winsor <- mutate_weights(     net,     transform_fn = function(x) {         q95 <- quantile(x, 0.95, na.rm = TRUE)         return(pmin(x, q95)) # Cap at 95th percentile     },     new_name = "verbCoop_winsorized" )  # Example 9: Only add constant (no transformation function) net_shifted <- mutate_weights(     net,     add_constant = 10,     new_name = "verbCoop_shifted" )  # Example 10: Don't keep original weights to save memory net_log_compact <- mutate_weights(     net,     transform_fn = log1p, # log(1 + x), handles zeros automatically     new_name = "log1p_verbCoop",     keep_original = FALSE )  # Example 11: Longitudinal network transformation if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Create longitudinal network net_longit <- netify(     icews,     actor1 = "i", actor2 = "j", time = "year",     symmetric = FALSE,     weight = "verbCoop",     actor_time_uniform = FALSE )  # Transform across all time periods net_longit_log <- mutate_weights(     net_longit,     transform_fn = log1p,     new_name = "log_verbCoop" ) } # }  # Example 12: Custom transformation with multiple operations net_custom <- mutate_weights(     net,     transform_fn = function(x) {         # Complex transformation: log, then standardize         x_log <- log(x + 1)         x_std <- (x_log - mean(x_log, na.rm = TRUE)) / sd(x_log, na.rm = TRUE)         return(x_std)     },     new_name = "verbCoop_log_std" )

what: Prepare netify data for network visualization ‚Äî net_plot_data
title: Prepare netify data for network visualization ‚Äî net_plot_data
text: net_plot_data processes netify object generates necessary components network visualization. function handles layout computation, aesthetic parameter organization, data structuring subsequent plotting ggplot2 visualization tools.

title: Prepare netify data for network visualization ‚Äî net_plot_data
code: net_plot_data(netlet, plot_args = list())

title: Prepare netify data for network visualization ‚Äî net_plot_data
text: netlet netify object (class "netify") containing network visualized. Must single-layer network (multilayer networks currently supported). plot_args list plotting arguments controlling visualization appearance behavior. Can include: Layout parameters: point_layout: Pre-computed node positions data.frame list data.frames (longitudinal networks). provided, overrides layout algorithm selection layout: Character string specifying igraph layout algorithm. Options: "nicely" (default), "fr" (Fruchterman-Reingold), "kk" (Kamada-Kawai), "circle", "star", "grid", "tree", "bipartite", others. See get_node_layout full list static_actor_positions: Logical. TRUE, maintains consistent node positions across time periods longitudinal networks which_static: Integer specifying time period use template static positions seed: Integer reproducible random layouts Display options: remove_isolates: Logical. Remove unconnected nodes (default: TRUE) add_edges: Logical. Include edges visualization (default: TRUE) curve_edges: Logical. Use curved edges instead straight (default: FALSE) add_points: Logical. Display nodes points (default: TRUE) add_text: Logical. Add text labels nodes (default: FALSE) add_label: Logical. Add boxed labels nodes (default: FALSE) Selective labeling: select_text: Character vector node names label text select_label: Character vector node names label boxes Additional aesthetic parameters processed adjust_plot_args gg_params.

title: Prepare netify data for network visualization ‚Äî net_plot_data
text: list three components creating network visualizations: plot_args: Processed plotting arguments defaults applied parameters validated. Includes layout display settings ggnet_params: Organized aesthetic parameters ggplot2 mapping. Contains separate specifications nodes, edges, text, labels static dynamic (data-mapped) aesthetics net_dfs: Data frames ready plotting: nodal_data: Node information including positions (x, y), attributes, additional variables edge_data: Edge information including endpoint coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) edge attributes

title: Prepare netify data for network visualization ‚Äî net_plot_data
text: function serves data preparation layer netify visualization, performing several operations: Data validation: Ensures input valid netify object Checks single-layer networks (multilayer supported) Validates ego networks contain one ego Layout computation: Generates node positions using specified algorithm provided Calculates edge endpoint coordinates based node positions Handles cross-sectional longitudinal layouts Data organization: Merges layout information network attributes Processes plotting arguments applies defaults Organizes aesthetic parameters ggplot2 compatibility Removes isolates requested Output structure: returned data structured direct use ggplot2 can customized. separation layout, aesthetics, data allows flexible visualization workflows.

title: Prepare netify data for network visualization ‚Äî net_plot_data
text: function primarily designed use netify's plot method can called directly custom visualization workflows. multilayer networks, use subset_netify extract individual layers visualization. ego networks multiple egos, create separate visualizations combine using packages like patchwork.

title: Prepare netify data for network visualization ‚Äî net_plot_data
text: Cassy Dorff, Shahryar Minhas

what: Create network object from various data types ‚Äî netify
title: Create network object from various data types ‚Äî netify
text: function takes various types network data (dyadic datasets, matrices, arrays, lists, igraph objects, network objects) outputs netify object.

title: Create network object from various data types ‚Äî netify
code: netify(   input,   actor1 = NULL,   actor2 = NULL,   time = NULL,   symmetric = TRUE,   mode = "unipartite",   weight = NULL,   sum_dyads = FALSE,   actor_time_uniform = TRUE,   actor_pds = NULL,   diag_to_NA = TRUE,   missing_to_zero = TRUE,   output_format = NULL,   nodal_vars = NULL,   dyad_vars = NULL,   dyad_vars_symmetric = rep(symmetric, length(dyad_vars)),   input_type = c("auto", "dyad_df", "netify_obj"),   nodelist = NULL,   ... )

title: Create network object from various data types ‚Äî netify
text: input data object netify. Can : data.frame (tibble/data.table) dyadic data matrix representing adjacency matrix 3D array representing longitudinal networks list matrices representing longitudinal networks igraph object network object (network package) list igraph network objects actor1 character: name actor 1 variable data (required data.frame inputs) actor2 character: name actor 2 variable data (required data.frame inputs) time character: name time variable data. Can contain numeric, Date, POSIXct/POSIXlt, character values. Non-numeric types converted numeric indices preserving original labels. time provided cross-sectional network created. symmetric logical: whether ties symmetric, default TRUE mode character: whether network unipartite bipartite, default unipartite weight character: name weighted edge variable data, default NULL sum_dyads logical: whether sum weight value exists repeating dyads actor_time_uniform logical: whether assume actors across full time series observed data TRUE means actors across full time series observed data outputted netify object array format. FALSE means actors come observed data "existence" determined data, meaning first year existence determined time point first event last year existence time point last event. Outputted netify object list format. actor_pds data.frame indicating start end time point every actor, can created using get_actor_time_info, unless provided estimated user based choice actor_time_uniform diag_to_NA logical: whether diagonals set NA, default TRUE missing_to_zero logical: whether missing values set zero, default TRUE output_format character: "cross_sec", "longit_array", "longit_list". specified time NULL output_format "cross_sec" time specified output_format default "longit_list". applies data.frame inputs. nodal_vars character vector: names nodal variables input added attributes netify object (data.frame inputs) dyad_vars character vector: names dyadic variables input added attributes netify object (data.frame inputs) dyad_vars_symmetric logical vector: whether ties symmetric, default use choice symmetric argument input_type character: force specific input type interpretation. Options "auto" (default), "dyad_df", "netify_obj". Use "dyad_df" force data.frame interpretation "netify_obj" force matrix/array/ igraph/network interpretation. nodelist character vector: optional list actors (nodes) included network. ensures isolates (nodes edges) properly represented. Particularly useful working edgelists contain active dyads. ... additional arguments passed to_netify processing network objects

title: Create network object from various data types ‚Äî netify
code: # load example directed event data from ICEWS # this data comes in the form of a dyadic # dataframe where all dyad pairs are listed data(icews)  # From a data.frame: generate a longitudional, directed and weighted network # where the weights are matlConf icews_matlConf <- netify(     input = icews,     actor1 = "i", actor2 = "j", time = "year",     symmetric = FALSE, weight = "matlConf" )  # From a matrix adj_matrix <- matrix(rbinom(100, 1, 0.3), 10, 10) net_from_matrix <- netify(adj_matrix)  # From an igraph object if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(igraph) g <- sample_gnp(10, 0.3) net_from_igraph <- netify(g) } # }

title: Extract measurements and dimensions from a netify object ‚Äî netify_measurements
text: list containing measurements netify object following components (availability depends netify type): Actor information: row_actors: Character vector (list) row actor names col_actors: Character vector (list) column actor names n_row_actors: Integer (list) count row actors n_col_actors: Integer (list) count column actors Temporal information: time: Character vector time period labels (NULL cross-sectional) n_time: Integer count time periods (NULL cross-sectional) Layer information: layers: Character vector layer names (NULL single layer) n_layers: Integer count layers (NULL single layer) Attribute information: nvars: Character vector nodal variable names n_nvars: Integer count nodal variables dvars: Character vector dyadic variable names n_dvars: Integer count dyadic variables

what: Convert netify objects to amen format ‚Äî netify_to_amen
title: Convert netify objects to amen format ‚Äî netify_to_amen
text: netify_to_amen (also available to_amen) transforms netify network objects data structure required amen package advanced network modeling. enables use Social Relations Models (SRM), Additive Multiplicative Effects (AME) models, network regression approaches implemented amen.

title: Convert netify objects to amen format ‚Äî netify_to_amen
code: netify_to_amen(netlet, lame = FALSE)  to_amen(netlet, lame = FALSE)

title: Convert netify objects to amen format ‚Äî netify_to_amen
text: netlet netify object (class "netify") containing network data. Must single-layer network. multilayer networks, first extract individual layers using subset_netify. lame Logical. Controls output format longitudinal data: FALSE (default): Formats output compatibility standard version amen package, uses array structures TRUE: Formats output compatibility netify-verse version called lame, supports longitudinal network modeling time-varying actor compositions features parameter ignored cross-sectional data.

title: Convert netify objects to amen format ‚Äî netify_to_amen
text: structure returned list depends data type lame parameter: cross-sectional data longitudinal lame = FALSE (standard amen): Y Network adjacency data numeric matrix array: Cross-sectional: Matrix dimensions [n_actors √ó n_actors] Longitudinal: Array dimensions [n_actors √ó n_actors √ó n_time] Contains edge weights binary indicators. Missing edges preserved NA. Xdyad Dyadic covariates array, NULL none exist: Cross-sectional: [n_actors √ó n_actors √ó n_covariates] Longitudinal: [n_actors √ó n_actors √ó n_covariates √ó n_time] slice contains one dyadic covariate across actor pairs. Xrow Sender/row actor attributes matrix array, NULL none exist: Cross-sectional: [n_actors √ó n_attributes] Longitudinal: [n_actors √ó n_attributes √ó n_time] Contains numeric attributes actors act senders. Xcol Receiver/column actor attributes, structured identically Xrow. symmetric networks, Xcol identical Xrow. bipartite networks, contains attributes second mode. longitudinal data lame = TRUE (lame package): Y list length T (time periods), element n √ó n relational matrix. Actor sets can vary across time periods. Xdyad list length T, element n √ó n √ó pd array dyadic covariates, NULL none exist Xrow list length T, element n √ó pr matrix nodal row covariates, NULL none exist Xcol list length T, element n √ó pc matrix nodal column covariates, NULL none exist

title: Convert netify objects to amen format ‚Äî netify_to_amen
text: Variable requirements: nodal attributes must numeric (integer double) Character factor variables must converted using function Missing values (NA) preserved can handled amen's models use format: Use lame = FALSE : Actor composition constant across time Use lame = TRUE : Actors enter/exit network time Want access features lame

title: Convert netify objects to amen format ‚Äî netify_to_amen
text: function performs several validation checks: Ensures single-layer networks (multilayer supported) Verifies nodal attributes numeric Maintains actor ordering original netify object

title: Convert netify objects to amen format ‚Äî netify_to_amen
text: Ha Eun Choi, Cassy Dorff, Colin Henry, Shahryar Minhas

title: Convert netify objects to amen format ‚Äî netify_to_amen
code: # Load example data data(icews)  # Create a netify object net <- netify(     icews[icews$year == 2010, ],     actor1 = "i", actor2 = "j",     symmetric = FALSE,     weight = "verbCoop" )  # Convert to amen format (standard) amen_data <- netify_to_amen(net) names(amen_data) # Y, Xdyad, Xrow, Xcol #> [1] "Y"     "Xdyad" "Xrow"  "Xcol"   if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # For longitudinal data with time-varying composition longit_net <- netify(     icews,     actor1 = "i", actor2 = "j", time = "year",     symmetric = FALSE,     weight = "verbCoop" )  # Convert to lame format lame_data <- netify_to_amen(longit_net, lame = TRUE) } # }

text: netlet netify object containing network data. Currently supports single-layer networks . multilayer networks, use subset_netify extract individual layers first. add_nodal_attribs Logical. TRUE (default), includes nodal attributes netify object vertex attributes igraph object. Set FALSE create network structure . add_dyad_attribs Logical. TRUE (default), includes dyadic attributes netify object edge attributes igraph object. Set FALSE exclude edge covariates.

title: Convert netify objects to igraph format ‚Äî netify_to_igraph
text: igraph object list igraph objects: Cross-sectional networks Returns single igraph object Longitudinal networks Returns named list igraph objects, names corresponding time periods resulting igraph object(s) : Vertices named according actors netify object Edge weights netify weight variable (present) Vertex attributes nodal variable (add_nodal_attribs = TRUE) Edge attributes dyadic variable (add_dyad_attribs = TRUE)

title: Convert netify objects to igraph format ‚Äî netify_to_igraph
text: conversion process handles different netify structures: Cross-sectional: Direct conversion single igraph object Longitudinal arrays: Internally converted list format, time slice becomes separate igraph object Longitudinal lists: time period converted separate igraph object directed networks, resulting igraph object directed. undirected networks, igraph object undirected. Edge weights netify object become edge weights igraph. longitudinal data includes actors appear disappear time, time period's igraph object contain actors present period.

text: netlet netify object containing network data. Currently supports single-layer networks . multilayer networks, use subset_netify extract individual layers first. add_nodal_attribs Logical. TRUE (default), includes nodal attributes netify object vertex attributes network object. Set FALSE create network structure . add_dyad_attribs Logical. TRUE (default), includes dyadic attributes netify object edge attributes network object. Set FALSE exclude edge covariates.

title: Convert netify objects to statnet network format ‚Äî netify_to_statnet
text: network object list network objects: Cross-sectional networks Returns single network object Longitudinal networks Returns named list network objects, names corresponding time periods resulting network object(s) : Vertices named according actors netify object Edge weights netify weight variable stored "weight" attribute Vertex attributes nodal variable (add_nodal_attribs = TRUE) Edge attributes dyadic variable (add_dyad_attribs = TRUE) Proper directedness based symmetric parameter netify object

title: Convert netify objects to statnet network format ‚Äî netify_to_statnet
text: conversion process handles different netify structures: Cross-sectional: Direct conversion single network object Longitudinal arrays: Internally converted list format, time slice becomes separate network object Longitudinal lists: time period converted separate network object statnet network format stores networks edgelist attributes, making memory-efficient sparse networks. nodal dyadic attributes netify object preserved can used subsequent ERGM modeling network analysis. longitudinal data, time period results independent network object. format suitable discrete-time network analysis pooled ERGM estimation across time periods.

title: Convert netify objects to statnet network format ‚Äî netify_to_statnet
text: function requires network package (part statnet) installed. ERGM modeling, ergm package (also part statnet) loaded creating network objects.

title: Convert netify objects to statnet network format ‚Äî netify_to_statnet
text: Ha Eun Choi, Cassy Dorff, Colin Henry, Shahryar Minhas

title: Convert netify objects to statnet network format ‚Äî netify_to_statnet
code: # Load example data data(icews)  # Cross-sectional example icews_10 <- icews[icews$year == 2010, ]  # Create netify object with attributes dvars <- c("matlCoop", "verbConf", "matlConf") nvars <- c("i_polity2", "i_log_gdp", "i_log_pop")  verbCoop_net <- netify(     icews_10,     actor1 = "i", actor2 = "j",     symmetric = FALSE,     weight = "verbCoop",     dyad_vars = dvars,     dyad_vars_symmetric = rep(FALSE, length(dvars)),     nodal_vars = nvars )  # Convert to statnet network object ntwk <- netify_to_statnet(verbCoop_net)  # Examine the result ntwk #>  Network attributes: #>   vertices = 152  #>   directed = TRUE  #>   hyper = FALSE  #>   loops = FALSE  #>   multiple = FALSE  #>   bipartite = FALSE  #>   verbCoop: 152x152 matrix #>   matlCoop: 152x152 matrix #>   verbConf: 152x152 matrix #>   matlConf: 152x152 matrix #>   total edges= 9976  #>     missing edges= 0  #>     non-missing edges= 9976  #>  #>  Vertex attribute names:  #>     i_log_gdp i_log_pop i_polity2 vertex.names  #>  #>  Edge attribute names not shown  network::network.size(ntwk) # number of vertices #> [1] 152 network::network.edgecount(ntwk) # number of edges #> [1] 9976 network::list.vertex.attributes(ntwk) # nodal attributes #> [1] "i_log_gdp"    "i_log_pop"    "i_polity2"    "na"           "vertex.names" network::list.edge.attributes(ntwk) # edge attributes #> [1] "matlConf_e" "matlCoop_e" "na"         "verbConf_e" "verbCoop"    # Access specific attributes network::get.vertex.attribute(ntwk, "i_polity2") # polity scores #>   [1]  NA   9   2  -2   8   5  10  10  -7  -5   5  -7   8   7   7  NA   8   9 #>  [19]   0   6   2  -4  10  10  -1  -2  10  -7   7   9  -4   5  10   0   9  -7 #>  [37]  10  10   2   8   5  -3   8  -6   9  -3  -4  10  10   3  -5   6  10   8 #>  [55]  10   8   1   6   6   0   7  10   9   8  -7   3  10   6  10   9  10  -3 #>  [73]  -6   8 -10   8  -7   4  -7   8   6   6  -7  10  10   9   0   6   6   7 #>  [91]  -2  10   8   9  10  -6   5  -6   6  10  10   9   3   4  10  -8   6   9 #> [109]   4   8   9   8  10  10 -10   9   4  -4 -10   7   7  -2  10  10   8   0 #> [127]   9  10   3  -2   5  10  10  -7  -3  -1   4  -2  10  -4  -9  -1   6  -8 #> [145]  10  10  10  -9  -7  -2   7   1 network::get.edge.attribute(ntwk, "matlCoop") # material cooperation #> NULL  # Check network properties network::is.directed(ntwk) # TRUE for this example #> [1] TRUE network::has.loops(ntwk) # FALSE (no self-ties) #> [1] FALSE  # Longitudinal example verbCoop_longit <- netify(     icews,     actor1 = "i", actor2 = "j", time = "year",     symmetric = FALSE,     weight = "verbCoop",     dyad_vars = dvars,     dyad_vars_symmetric = rep(FALSE, length(dvars)),     nodal_vars = nvars )  # Convert to list of network objects ntwk_list <- netify_to_statnet(verbCoop_longit)  # Examine structure length(ntwk_list) # number of time periods #> [1] 13 names(ntwk_list) # time period labels #>  [1] "2002" "2003" "2004" "2005" "2006" "2007" "2008" "2009" "2010" "2011" #> [11] "2012" "2013" "2014"  # Access specific time period ntwk_2002 <- ntwk_list[["2002"]] ntwk_2002 #>  Network attributes: #>   vertices = 152  #>   directed = TRUE  #>   hyper = FALSE  #>   loops = FALSE  #>   multiple = FALSE  #>   bipartite = FALSE  #>   verbCoop: 152x152 matrix #>   matlCoop: 152x152 matrix #>   verbConf: 152x152 matrix #>   matlConf: 152x152 matrix #>   total edges= 8692  #>     missing edges= 0  #>     non-missing edges= 8692  #>  #>  Vertex attribute names:  #>     i_log_gdp i_log_pop i_polity2 vertex.names  #>  #>  Edge attribute names not shown   if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Use with ergm for modeling (requires ergm package) library(ergm) model <- ergm(ntwk ~ edges + mutual + nodematch("i_polity2")) } # }

what: Low-level constructor for netify objects ‚Äî new_netify
title: Low-level constructor for netify objects ‚Äî new_netify
text: new_netify (also available new_netlet) low-level constructor creates netify objects raw matrix, array, list data structures. function automatically detects network properties sets appropriate attributes, making useful converting existing network data netify format.

title: Low-level constructor for netify objects ‚Äî new_netify
code: new_netify(data, ...)

title: Low-level constructor for netify objects ‚Äî new_netify
text: data network data structure convert: Matrix: Creates cross-sectional netify object 3D array: Creates longitudinal array netify object (dimensions: actors √ó actors √ó time) List matrices: Creates longitudinal list netify object (useful time-varying actor composition) ... Additional parameters set attributes netify object. Common parameters include: symmetric: Logical indicating network undirected mode: "unipartite" "bipartite" weight: Name edge weight variable diag_to_NA: Whether set diagonal NA missing_to_zero: Whether treat missing edges zeros nodal_data: Data frame node attributes dyad_data: Dyadic attributes (see netify documentation) provided, properties automatically detected data.

title: Low-level constructor for netify objects ‚Äî new_netify
text: netify object class "netify" appropriate structure: matrices: single netify matrix netify_type = "cross_sec" arrays: netify array netify_type = "longit_array" lists: netify list netify_type = "longit_list", element netify object netify objects include automatically detected user-specified attributes network properties, making ready use netify functions.

title: Low-level constructor for netify objects ‚Äî new_netify
text: Automatic property detection: properties explicitly provided, new_netify intelligently detects: Symmetry: Checks matrix equals transpose Mode: Infers unipartite/bipartite dimensions actor names Edge weights: Detects binary (0/1) vs. weighted networks Diagonal treatment: Checks diagonal contains NAs Missing values: Determines NAs exist -diagonal Actor composition: longitudinal data, detects actors remain constant vary time Naming conventions: row/column names provided: Unipartite networks: Actors named "a1", "a2", ... Bipartite networks: Row actors "r1", "r2", ...; column actors "c1", "c2", ... Time periods: Named "1", "2", ... specified Longitudinal data handling: longitudinal networks: Arrays assume constant actor composition across time Lists allow time-varying actor composition time slice list becomes separate cross-sectional netify object Properties detected across time periods (e.g., symmetric time slices symmetric)

title: Low-level constructor for netify objects ‚Äî new_netify
text: low-level constructor primarily intended package developers advanced users. users use higher-level netify() function, provides comprehensive data validation preprocessing. function support multilayer networks directly. create multilayer networks, create separate netify objects combine layer_netify(). function attempts detect network properties automatically, explicitly providing parameters recommended clarity.

title: Low-level constructor for netify objects ‚Äî new_netify
text: Cassy Dorff, Shahryar Minhas

what: Preview subsets of network data from netify objects ‚Äî peek
title: Preview subsets of network data from netify objects ‚Äî peek
text: peek provides convenient way inspect portions network data stored netify objects. Rather displaying entire networks (can overwhelming large datasets), function allows examine specific actors, time periods, layers data exploration, verification, debugging.

title: Preview subsets of network data from netify objects ‚Äî peek
code: peek(netlet, actors = NULL, from = 3, to = 3, time = 1, layers = NULL)

title: Preview subsets of network data from netify objects ‚Äî peek
text: netlet netify object preview. Can cross-sectional, longitudinal (array list format), /multilayer. actors Character vector actor names numeric indices subset. Selects actors senders receivers (extracts subgraph among actors). Overridden specified. Specifies actors display senders ties (row actors adjacency matrix). Can : Single number: Shows first n actors (e.g., = 5 displays actors 1-5) Numeric vector: Shows specific positions (e.g., = c(1,3,5) displays 1st, 3rd, 5th actors) Character vector: Shows named actors (e.g., = c("USA", "China") displays specific countries) NULL: Shows row actors (default 3) bipartite networks, represents actors first mode. Specifies actors display receivers ties (column actors adjacency matrix). Accepts input types . bipartite networks, columns represent actors second mode. Default 3. time longitudinal networks, specifies time periods display. Can : Single number: Shows nth time period (e.g., time = 1 shows first time period) Numeric vector: Shows specific time indices (e.g., time = c(1,5,10)) Character vector: Shows named time periods (e.g., time = c("2002", "2006") displays specific years) NULL: Shows time periods Default 1 (first time period ). Ignored cross-sectional networks. layers multilayer networks, specifies layer(s) display. Must character vector matching layer names netify object (e.g., layers = c("trade", "alliance")). single-layer networks, parameter ignored. Default NULL (shows layers).

title: Preview subsets of network data from netify objects ‚Äî peek
text: Returns subset raw network data (without netify attributes): Cross-sectional networks Single layer: Returns matrix selected rows columns Multilayer: Returns 3D array (rows √ó columns √ó layers) Longitudinal networks Array format: Returns array dimensions depending selection List format: Returns list matrices, one per selected time period returned objects preserve dimension names (actor names, time labels, layer names) easy interpretation. Single dimensions automatically dropped.

title: Preview subsets of network data from netify objects ‚Äî peek
text: Purpose Design peek designed lightweight data exploration tool. Unlike subset_netify, creates new netify objects attributes preserved, peek returns raw network data quick inspection. makes ideal : Verifying data structure content Checking specific relationships Debugging data issues Quick visual inspection network patterns Understanding Network Directions directed networks: represents actors sending ties (-ties) represents actors receiving ties (-ties) Cell [,j] contains tie actor actor j example, cell ["USA", "China"] = 5, means USA sends tie strength 5 China. Smart Selection Behavior function includes several convenience features: Single numbers expanded ranges (e.g., = 5 becomes first 5 actors) --bounds indices silently ignored (errors exploration) Character names matched actor labels Dimension reduction: one time period layer selected, dimension dropped output

title: Preview subsets of network data from netify objects ‚Äî peek
text: Important distinctions: Use peek quick data inspection (returns raw matrices) Use subset_netify create new netify objects attributes Use get_raw extract raw data netify object multiple layers present layer selection specified, layers returned warning message remind multilayer structure.

title: Preview subsets of network data from netify objects ‚Äî peek
text: Cassy Dorff, Shahryar Minhas

title: Preview subsets of network data from netify objects ‚Äî peek
code: # Load example data data(icews)  # Example 1: Basic usage with cross-sectional network icews_10 <- icews[icews$year == 2010, ] net <- netify(     icews_10,     actor1 = "i", actor2 = "j",     weight = "verbCoop" )  # Default: see first 3 actors (both sending and receiving) peek(net) #>             Afghanistan Albania Algeria #> Afghanistan          NA       5       5 #> Albania               5      NA       1 #> Algeria               5       1      NA  # See first 5 senders and first 5 receivers peek(net, from = 5, to = 5) #>             Afghanistan Albania Algeria Angola Argentina #> Afghanistan          NA       5       5      0         2 #> Albania               5      NA       1      0         0 #> Algeria               5       1      NA      6         0 #> Angola peek(net,     from = c("United States", "China"),     to = c("Russia", "India", "Brazil") ) #>               India Brazil #> United States  3324    369 #> China          1209    257  # Use actors parameter to see subgraph peek(net,     actors = c("United States", "China", "Russia") ) #>               United States China #> United States            NA  4937 #> China                  4937    NA  # Example 3: Longitudinal network net_longit <- netify(     icews,     actor1 = "i", actor2 = "j", time = "year",     weight = "matlConf" )  # See first 5 actors in specific years peek(net_longit,
