what: Pivot a dyadic variable to become the network ‚Äî pivot_dyad_to_network
title: Pivot a dyadic variable to become the network ‚Äî pivot_dyad_to_network
text: pivot_dyad_to_network swaps dyadic attribute main network netify object. useful want analyze different relationship type stored dyadic attribute. example, network represents trade relationships FDI stored dyadic attribute, can pivot make FDI main network.

title: Pivot a dyadic variable to become the network ‚Äî pivot_dyad_to_network
code: pivot_dyad_to_network(   netlet,   dyad_var,   make_network_dyad_var = TRUE,   network_var_name = NULL,   symmetric = NULL,   weight_type = NULL,   diag_to_NA = NULL,   missing_to_zero = NULL )

title: Pivot a dyadic variable to become the network ‚Äî pivot_dyad_to_network
text: netlet netify object containing network dyadic attributes dyad_var Character string naming dyadic variable become new network. Must exist netlet's dyad_data attribute. make_network_dyad_var Logical. TRUE (default), current network preserved dyadic attribute. network_var_name Character string specifying name old network converted dyadic attribute. NULL (default), uses current weight attribute name available, otherwise "old_network". symmetric Logical NULL. Specifies whether new network treated symmetric. NULL (default), attempts detect dyadic variable's symmetry setting data structure. weight_type Character string describing type weight new network (e.g., "trade_volume", "fdi_amount"). NULL (default), uses dyad_var name. diag_to_NA Logical. Whether set diagonal values NA new network. NULL (default), inherits original netlet. missing_to_zero Logical. Whether treat missing values zeros new network. NULL (default), inherits original netlet.

title: Pivot a dyadic variable to become the network ‚Äî pivot_dyad_to_network
text: netify object dyadic variable main network (optionally) old network preserved dyadic attribute. attributes dyadic variables preserved.

title: Pivot a dyadic variable to become the network ‚Äî pivot_dyad_to_network
text: function handles different netify types appropriately: cross-sectional networks: performs simple matrix swap longitudinal arrays: swaps matrices across time periods longitudinal lists: swaps matrices time period multilayer networks: swaps within layer new network different properties original (e.g., different symmetry weight type), function updates netify attributes accordingly. bipartite networks, new network always treated asymmetric. dyadic variable originally specified symmetry information via add_dyad_vars(), information used unless overridden symmetric parameter.

title: Pivot a dyadic variable to become the network ‚Äî pivot_dyad_to_network
text: Shahryar Minhas

title: Pivot a dyadic variable to become the network ‚Äî pivot_dyad_to_network
code: # Load example data data(icews)  # Create a netify object with verbal cooperation as the main network # and material cooperation as a dyadic attribute icews_10 <- icews[icews$year == 2010, ]  net <- netify(     icews_10,     actor1 = "i", actor2 = "j",     symmetric = FALSE,     weight = "verbCoop" )  net <- add_dyad_vars(     net,     icews_10,     actor1 = "i", actor2 = "j",     dyad_vars = "matlCoop",     dyad_vars_symmetric = FALSE )  # Check the current network print(net) #> ‚úî Hello, you have created network data, yay! #> ‚Ä¢ Unipartite #> ‚Ä¢ Asymmetric #> ‚Ä¢ Weights from `verbCoop` #> ‚Ä¢ Cross-Sectional #> ‚Ä¢ # Unique Actors: 152 #> Network Summary Statistics: #>           dens miss   mean recip trans #> verbCoop 0.432    0 18.134 0.982 0.639 #> ‚Ä¢ Nodal Features: None #> ‚Ä¢ Dyad Features: matlCoop  # Pivot to make material cooperation the main network net_pivoted <- pivot_dyad_to_network(     net,     dyad_var = "matlCoop",     network_var_name = "verbCoop" ) #> ‚Ñπ Auto-detected symmetry for 'matlCoop': asymmetric #> ‚úî Successfully pivoted 'matlCoop' to be the main network #> ‚Ñπ Previous network preserved as dyadic variable 'verbCoop'  # The main network is now material cooperation print(net_pivoted) #> ‚úî Hello, you have created network data, yay! #> ‚Ä¢ Unipartite #> ‚Ä¢ Asymmetric #> ‚Ä¢ Weighted: matlCoop #> ‚Ä¢ Cross-Sectional #> ‚Ä¢ # Unique Actors: 152 #> Network Summary Statistics: #>           dens   miss  mean recip trans #> verbCoop 0.092 -0.007 0.467 0.442 0.333 #> ‚Ä¢ Nodal Features: None #> ‚Ä¢ Dyad Features: verbCoop  # The old network (verbal cooperation) is preserved as a dyadic attribute attr(net_pivoted, "dyad_data")[["1"]][["verbCoop"]][1:5, 1:5] #>             Afghanistan Albania Algeria Angola Argentina #> Afghanistan          NA       0       0      0         1 #> Albania               5      NA       0      0         0 #> Algeria               5       1      NA      8         0 #> Angola                0       0       6     NA         7 #> Argentina             2       0       0      8        NA

what: Plotting method for netify objects ‚Äî plot.netify
title: Plotting method for netify objects ‚Äî plot.netify
text: Creates customizable network visualizations netify objects using ggplot2. Supports cross-sectional longitudinal networks extensive options mapping network attributes visual properties.

title: Plotting method for netify objects ‚Äî plot.netify
code: # S3 method for class 'netify' plot(x, ...)

title: Plotting method for netify objects ‚Äî plot.netify
text: x 'netify' object containing network data visualize. ... Additional arguments controlling plot appearance:

title: Plotting method for netify objects ‚Äî plot.netify
text: ggplot2 object can customized additional layers, scales, themes, etc. longitudinal networks, includes facets time period. return_components = TRUE, returns list plot components can manually assembled modified.

title: Plotting method for netify objects ‚Äî plot.netify
text: Naming Conventions: function supports two naming styles parameters: Recommended: Use node_* node attributes *_by variable mappings (e.g., node_size_by = "degree") Legacy: Use point_* nodes *_var variables (e.g., point_size_var = "degree") Default Behaviors: weighted networks, edge transparency maps weight default directed networks, arrows added automatically longitudinal networks, time periods shown facets Isolates removed default (set remove_isolates = FALSE keep) Customization Tips: Use mutate_weight handle skewed weight distributions Combine fixed variable aesthetics (e.g., fixed color variable size) Add ggplot2 layers plot call customization Use select_text selective labeling dense networks

title: Plotting method for netify objects ‚Äî plot.netify
text: layout Character string specifying igraph layout algorithm. Options include: "nicely" (default), "fr" (Fruchterman-Reingold), "kk" (Kamada-Kawai), "circle", "star", "grid", "tree", "bipartite" (bipartite networks), "randomly", others. ego networks, additional options available: "radial" (ego-centric optional grouping) "concentric" (ego center alters rings). See get_node_layout get_ego_layout full details. point_layout Optional data.frame list data.frames containing pre-computed node positions columns 'actor', 'x', 'y'. Overrides layout provided. static_actor_positions Logical. longitudinal networks, node positions remain constant across time? Default FALSE. which_static Integer. static_actor_positions = TRUE, time period's layout use template? NULL (default), creates composite layout time periods. seed Integer reproducible layouts. Default 6886.

title: Plotting method for netify objects ‚Äî plot.netify
text: add_edges Logical. Display edges? Default TRUE. add_points Logical. Display nodes points? Default TRUE. add_text Logical. Add text labels nodes? Default FALSE. add_text_repel Logical. Add text labels automatic repositioning avoid overlaps? Default FALSE. TRUE, overrides add_text. Uses ggrepel positioning. add_label Logical. Add boxed labels nodes? Default FALSE. add_label_repel Logical. Add boxed labels automatic repositioning avoid overlaps? Default FALSE. TRUE, overrides add_label. Uses ggrepel positioning. remove_isolates Logical. Remove unconnected nodes? Default TRUE. curve_edges Logical. Use curved edges? Default FALSE. use_theme_netify Logical. Apply netify theme? Default TRUE. facet_type Character. multilayer longitudinal networks, controls faceting style: "grid" (default) creates 2D grid time √ó layer, "wrap" creates wrapped facets combined time-layer labels. facet_ncol Integer. Number columns facet_wrap layouts. used facet_type = "wrap" single-dimension faceting. rescale_edge_weights Logical. multilayer networks, edge weights rescaled common 0-1 range across layers? useful layers different weight scales. Default FALSE.

title: Plotting method for netify objects ‚Äî plot.netify
text: node_filter expression filter nodes. expression can reference nodal attribute. example: node_filter = degree_total > 5 show nodes total degree greater 5. expression evaluated context nodal data, node-level variable can used. edge_filter expression filter edges. expression can reference edge attribute (including 'weight' weighted networks). example: edge_filter = weight > 0.5 show edges weight greater 0.5. expression evaluated context edge data, edge-level variable can used. time_filter longitudinal networks, vector time periods include plot. Can numeric indices character labels matching time dimension. NULL (default), time periods plotted. cross-sectional networks, parameter ignored.

title: Plotting method for netify objects ‚Äî plot.netify
text: Fixed aesthetics (nodes): node_size point_size Numeric. Size nodes. node_color point_color Color node borders. node_fill point_fill Fill color nodes (note fill work certain shapes). node_shape point_shape Shape nodes (see ?pch). node_alpha point_alpha Transparency (0-1). node_stroke point_stroke Width node borders. Variable aesthetics (mapped data): node_size_by point_size_var Column name size mapping. node_color_by point_color_var Column name border color. node_fill_by point_fill_var Column name fill color (note fill work certain shapes). node_shape_by point_shape_var Column name shape. node_alpha_by point_alpha_var Column name transparency.

title: Plotting method for netify objects ‚Äî plot.netify
text: Fixed aesthetics: edge_color Color edges. Default "black". edge_linewidth Width edges. Default 0.5. edge_linetype Line type (1=solid, 2=dashed, etc.). edge_alpha Transparency (0-1). edge_curvature Curvature amount curve_edges = TRUE. edge_arrow Arrow specification directed networks. Example: arrow(length = unit(0.2, "cm")). adjust_arrow_endpoints Logical. arrow endpoints adjusted stop node boundaries? Default FALSE. affects directed networks. edge_arrow_gap Numeric. Additional gap arrow tip node boundary proportion node radius (0-1). Default 0.2. used adjust_arrow_endpoints = TRUE. edge_arrow_size_scale Numeric. Scale factor converting node sizes coordinate units. NULL (default), automatically calculated based plot range. Variable aesthetics: edge_color_by edge_color_var Column name color mapping. edge_linewidth_by edge_linewidth_var Column name width. edge_linetype_by edge_linetype_var Column name line type. edge_alpha_by edge_alpha_var Column name transparency. weighted networks, defaults weight variable specified.

title: Plotting method for netify objects ‚Äî plot.netify
text: Selective labeling: select_text Character vector node names show text. used, text labels automatically use geom_text_repel avoid overlaps. select_text_display Alternative text display (length select_text). select_label Character vector node names show boxes. used, labels automatically use geom_label_repel avoid overlaps. select_label_display Alternative labels (length select_label). Text aesthetics: text_size Fixed size text. Default 3.88. text_color Fixed color text. Default "black". text_alpha Fixed transparency text. text_size_by Variable map text size. text_color_by Variable map text color. Label (boxed text) aesthetics similar parameters label_ prefix. Text repel parameters (add_text_repel = TRUE): text_repel_force Force repulsion overlapping text. Default 1. text_repel_max_overlaps Maximum number overlaps tolerate. Default 10. text_repel_box_padding Padding around text. Default 0.25. text_repel_point_padding Padding around points. Default 0. text_repel_segment_color Color connecting segments. Default "grey50". Label repel parameters (add_label_repel = TRUE): Similar text_repel label_repel_ prefix  label_repel_label_padding Padding around label boxes. Default 0.25. label_repel_label_r Radius label box corners. Default 0.15.

title: Plotting method for netify objects ‚Äî plot.netify
text: Customize legend titles: node_size_label point_size_label Legend title size. node_color_label point_color_label Legend title color. edge_alpha_label Legend title edge transparency. edge_color_label Legend title edge color.

title: Plotting method for netify objects ‚Äî plot.netify
text: highlight Character vector node names highlight different colors. Non-highlighted nodes colored grey. Highlighted nodes can also automatically enlarged highlight_size_increase greater 1. highlight_color Named vector colors highlighted nodes. NULL, uses default distinct colors (red, blue, green 3 nodes, color palette ). Names match values highlight parameter. Example: c('USA' = 'blue', 'China' = 'red', 'Russia' = 'green'). highlight_label Title highlight legend. Default "Highlighted". highlight_size_increase Numeric factor(s) increase size highlighted nodes. Can single value (applied highlighted nodes) vector length length(highlight) + 1 value corresponds highlighted node last value applies "" nodes. Default 1 (size increase). Example: c(3, 1, 1, 0.5) 3 highlighted nodes first 3x larger, next two normal size, others half size. show_other_in_legend Logical. Include "" category legend? Default FALSE. FALSE, highlighted nodes appear legend.

title: Plotting method for netify objects ‚Äî plot.netify
text: ego networks (created ego_netify), additional layout options control ego-centric visualization: ego_group_by Character string specifying nodal attribute use grouping alters ego layouts. "radial" layout, creates sectors. "concentric" layout, determines ring assignment. ego_order_by Character string specifying nodal attribute use ordering alters within groups rings. Common options include "degree_total". ego_weight_to_distance Logical. weighted networks "radial" layout, edge weights determine distance ego? Higher weights place alters closer ego. Default FALSE. ego_ring_gap Numeric (0-1). Gap concentric rings proportion radius. "concentric" layout. Default 0.3. ego_size Numeric. Relative size central area reserved ego. Larger values create space ego alters. Default 0.1.

title: Plotting method for netify objects ‚Äî plot.netify
text: mutate_weight Function transform edge weights plotting. Example: log1p log(x+1) transformation. Applied mapping aesthetics. return_components Logical. Return plot components instead assembled plot? Useful manual customization. Default FALSE. style style function (e.g., style_budapest). Applies complete visual style including colors, shapes, layout preferences.

title: Plotting method for netify objects ‚Äî plot.netify
code: # Load example data data(icews)  # Basic cross-sectional network icews_10 <- icews[icews$year == 2010, ] net_10 <- netify(     icews_10,     actor1 = "i", actor2 = "j",     symmetric = FALSE,     weight = "verbCoop" )  # Simple plot plot(net_10)   # add nodal stats to netlet net_10 <- add_node_vars(     net_10,     summary_actor(net_10),     "actor" )  # Customized plot with new naming convention plot(net_10,     edge_color = "lightgrey",     node_size_by = "degree_total", # Instead of point_size_var     node_color = "steelblue",     edge_alpha_by = "verbCoop", # Instead of edge_alpha_var     node_size_label = "Degree",     edge_alpha_label = "Verbal Cooperation" )   # Longitudinal network example net_longit <- netify(     icews,     actor1 = "i", actor2 = "j",     time = "year",     symmetric = FALSE,     weight = "verbCoop",     nodal_vars = c("i_polity2", "i_log_gdp") )  # Add network statistics net_longit <- add_node_vars(     net_longit,     summary_actor(net_longit),     actor = "actor",     time = "time" )  # Plot with multiple aesthetics plot(net_longit,     # Edges     edge_color = "grey70",     mutate_weight = log1p, # Transform weights     # Nodes     node_size_by = "degree_total",     node_color_by = "i_polity2",     # Labels     node_size_label = "Total Degree",     node_color_label = "Polity Score",     edge_alpha_label = "Log(Verbal Coop.)",     # Layout     static_actor_positions = TRUE # Keep positions constant )   # Selective labeling example plot(net_10,     node_size_by = "degree_total",     select_text = c("United States", "China", "Russian Federation"),     text_size = 3,     text_color = "darkred" ) #> Warning: Removed 149 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_text_repel()`).   # choose alternative labels for selected text plot(net_10,     node_size_by = "degree_total",     select_text = c("United States", "China", "Russian Federation"),     select_text_display = c("USA", "CHN", "RUS"),     text_size = 3,     text_color = "darkred" ) #> Warning: Removed 149 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_text_repel()`).    # Time subsetting example plot(net_longit,     time_filter = c("2010", "2011", "2012") )   # Node subsetting example # democracies with high GDP plot(net_longit, node_filter = ~ i_polity2 > 6 & i_log_gdp > 25)   # use return_components=TRUE # to get back ggplot2 pieces of plot g10 <- plot(     net_10,     node_alpha = .8,     arrow = ggplot2::arrow(length = ggplot2::unit(0.01, "inches")),     node_size_by = "degree_total",     node_size_label = "Log(Degree)",     edge_alpha_label = "Log(Verbal Coop.)",     remove_isolates = TRUE,     mutate_weight = log1p,     return_components = TRUE )  # Manually assemble with custom modifications # to scale aesthetics such as edges g10$base +     netify_edge(g10) +     ggplot2::scale_alpha_continuous(range = c(0.01, 0.2)) +     netify_node(g10) +     theme_netify()

title: Visualize actor-level network statistics ‚Äî plot_actor_stats
text: plot_actor_stats creates visualizations actor-level statistics summary_actor() output. function automatically adapts data structure (cross-sectional/longitudinal, single/multilayer) offers two main visualization approaches: distribution across actors tracking specific actors.

title: Visualize actor-level network statistics ‚Äî plot_actor_stats
code: plot_actor_stats(   summary_df,   longitudinal = ifelse("time" %in% colnames(summary_df), TRUE, FALSE),   multilayer = ifelse("layer" %in% colnames(summary_df), TRUE, FALSE),   across_actor = TRUE,   specific_stats = NULL,   specific_actors = NULL )

title: Visualize actor-level network statistics ‚Äî plot_actor_stats
text: summary_df data frame summary_actor() containing actor-level statistics. Must include "actor" column. May include "time" column longitudinal data "layer" column multilayer networks. longitudinal Logical indicating whether treat data longitudinal. NULL (default), automatically detected based presence "time" column. Set FALSE one unique time point exists. multilayer Logical indicating whether treat data multilayer. NULL (default), automatically detected based presence "layer" column. Set FALSE one unique layer exists. across_actor Logical. TRUE (default), visualizes distribution statistics across actors. FALSE, focuses tracking specific actors. TRUE specific_actors provided, shows distribution actors. specific_stats Character vector statistic names plot. NULL (default), plots available statistics. Must match column names summary_df. specific_actors Character vector actor names highlight focus . NULL (default) across_actor = FALSE, includes actors (warning > 25 actors). Must match values "actor" column.

title: Visualize actor-level network statistics ‚Äî plot_actor_stats
text: ggplot object can customized saved. plot type depends data structure parameters: Cross-sectional, across actors: Density plots rug plots Cross-sectional, specific actors: Beeswarm plots Longitudinal, across actors: Ridge density plots time Longitudinal, specific actors: Line plots time plots faceted statistic , applicable, layer.

title: Visualize actor-level network statistics ‚Äî plot_actor_stats
text: Visualization logic: function chooses appropriate visualizations based data structure: Distribution plots (across_actor = TRUE): Show statistics distributed across actor population Actor-specific plots (across_actor = FALSE): Track individual actors, specified actors highlighted color others appear gray plots use theme_stat_netify() consistent styling across netify visualizations. multilayer longitudinal data across_actor = FALSE, consider using specific_stats avoid overcrowded facets.

title: Visualize actor-level network statistics ‚Äî plot_actor_stats
text: Cassy Dorff, Shahryar Minhas

title: Visualize network-level statistics ‚Äî plot_graph_stats
text: plot_graph_stats creates line bar plots visualize network-level statistics across multiple networks, time points, layers. function designed work output summary_net() similar functions produce network-level summary statistics.

title: Visualize network-level statistics ‚Äî plot_graph_stats
code: plot_graph_stats(summary_df, type = "line", specific_stats = NULL)

title: Visualize network-level statistics ‚Äî plot_graph_stats
text: summary_df data frame containing network-level statistics, typically summary_net(). Must include "net" column identifying network time point. May include "layer" column multilayer networks. columns contain numeric statistics plot. type Character string specifying plot type. Options : "line": Line plot points (default). Best temporal data "bar": Bar plot grouped bars. Required multilayer non-temporal data specific_stats Character vector statistic names plot. NULL (default), plots numeric columns summary_df. Must match column names exactly.

title: Visualize network-level statistics ‚Äî plot_graph_stats
text: ggplot object displaying specified statistics. plot structure depends data: Single time/network: Returns error (single row plottable) Multiple times/networks: Line bar plot faceted statistic Multilayer temporal: Line plots colored layer Multilayer non-temporal: Grouped bar plots layer plots faceted statistic free y-axis scales better comparison across different value ranges.

title: Visualize network-level statistics ‚Äî plot_graph_stats
text: Data structure detection: function automatically detects structure data: Longitudinal: Multiple unique values "net" column Multilayer: Multiple unique values "layer" column Single network: one row (returns error suggestion) Plot type selection: Line plots preferred temporal data show trends Bar plots automatically selected multilayer non-temporal data Bar plots can useful comparing discrete time points Faceting behavior: statistic gets facet panel : Independent y-axis scales (scales = "free_y") Shared x-axis across panels Automatic layout based number statistics

title: Visualize network-level statistics ‚Äî plot_graph_stats
text: function requires least two networks/time points create meaningful plot. single network summaries, consider using table format instead.

title: Visualize network-level statistics ‚Äî plot_graph_stats
text: Ha Eun Choi, Cassy Dorff, Shahryar Minhas

title: Visualize homophily analysis results ‚Äî plot_homophily
text: Creates visualizations homophily analysis results homophily(). function can create different types plots including similarity distributions, comparison plots across multiple attributes, temporal evolution plots.

title: Visualize homophily analysis results ‚Äî plot_homophily
code: plot_homophily(   homophily_results,   netlet = NULL,   type = c("distribution", "comparison", "temporal"),   attribute = NULL,   method = "correlation",   sample_size = NULL,   colors = c("#2E86AB", "#F18F01"),   ... )

title: Visualize homophily analysis results ‚Äî plot_homophily
text: homophily_results Data frame output homophily() list data frames comparison plots. netlet Optional. netify object used analysis. Required distribution plots extract actual similarity data. type Character string specifying plot type: "distribution" Shows similarity score distributions connected vs unconnected pairs (requires netlet) "comparison" Compares homophily across multiple attributes "temporal" Shows homophily evolution time (longitudinal data) attribute Character string. distribution plots, specifies attribute visualize. match attribute used homophily(). method Character string. distribution plots, similarity method used. match method used homophily(). sample_size Integer. distribution plots large networks, number dyad pairs sample visualization. Default NULL (use pairs). colors Character vector two colors connected/unconnected significant/non-significant pairs. Default uses package theme colors. ... Additional arguments passed ggplot2 functions.

title: Subset netify objects ‚Äî subset.netify
text: Extracts subset netify object based specified actors, time periods, /layers preserving netify attributes structure.

title: Subset netify objects ‚Äî subset.netify
code: # S3 method for class 'netify' subset(   x,   actors = NULL,   time = NULL,   layers = NULL,   from = NULL,   to = NULL,   ... )

title: Subset netify objects ‚Äî subset.netify
text: x netify object subset actors Character vector actor names numeric indices subset. Extracts subgraph among actors (includes ties actors). Default NULL, includes actors. time Time periods subset. Can : Numeric vector: used indices time dimension Character vector: matched time dimension labels NULL: includes time periods (default) layers Character vector layer names subset multilayer networks. single-layer networks, ignored. multilayer networks, least one layer must specified. Character vector actor names numeric indices actors sending ties (row actors). Overrides actors. Set NULL include sending actors. bipartite networks, refers actors first mode. Character vector actor names numeric indices actors receiving ties (column actors). Overrides actors. Set NULL include receiving actors. bipartite networks, refers actors second mode. ... Additional arguments (currently unused)

title: Subset netify objects ‚Äî subset.netify
text: netify object containing requested subset : Subsetted adjacency matrix/matrices Corresponding nodal attributes (filtered included actors/times) Corresponding dyadic attributes (filtered included actor pairs/times) Updated netify attributes reflecting new dimensions returned object's structure depends subset: one time period selected longitudinal data, returns cross-sectional one layer selected multilayer data, returns single-layer Otherwise, maintains original structure type

title: Subset netify objects ‚Äî subset.netify
text: function netify-aware wrapper around peek function, handles raw data extraction. peek returns raw matrices/arrays, subset additionally: Preserves updates netify attributes Filters nodal dyadic attribute data match subset Adjusts netify type dimensions change (e.g., longitudinal cross-sectional) Maintains consistency network data attributes parameters allow precise control ties include: Use actors get ties among set actors (subgraph extraction) Use get ties sent specific actors Use get ties received specific actors Use get ties specific sets actors bipartite networks, refers actors first mode (e.g., people) refers actors second mode (e.g., organizations).

title: Subset netify objects ‚Äî subset.netify
text: subsetting longitudinal data single time period, function automatically converts result cross-sectional netify object. Similarly, subsetting multilayer data single layer produces single-layer object.

title: Subset netify objects ‚Äî subset.netify
text: Cassy Dorff, Shahryar Minhas

title: Subset netify objects ‚Äî subset.netify
code: # load example directed event data from ICEWS data(icews)  # generate a longitudional netify object # with both dyadic and nodal attributes icews_matlConf <- netify(     icews,     actor1 = "i", actor2 = "j", time = "year",     symmetric = FALSE, weight = "matlConf",     nodal_vars = c("i_polity2", "i_log_gdp", "i_log_pop"),     dyad_vars = c("matlCoop", "verbCoop", "verbConf"),     dyad_vars_symmetric = c(FALSE, FALSE, FALSE) )  # subset to a few countries using S3 method icews_subset <- subset(     icews_matlConf,     actors = c(         "United States", "United Kingdom",         "Russian Federation", "China"     ) )  # subset to a few countries and a few years icews_subset_2 <- subset(     icews_matlConf,     actors = c(         "United States", "United Kingdom",         "Russian Federation", "China"     ),     time = c("2010", "2011") )  # can also use subset_netify directly icews_subset_3 <- subset_netify(     netlet = icews_matlConf,     actors = c(         "United States", "United Kingdom",         "Russian Federation", "China"     ),     time = c("2010", "2011") )

what: Calculate graph-level statistics for netify objects ‚Äî summary.netify
title: Calculate graph-level statistics for netify objects ‚Äî summary.netify
text: Computes comprehensive graph-level statistics netify objects, including density, reciprocity, centralization measures, custom metrics. Handles cross-sectional longitudinal networks, well multilayer structures.

title: Calculate graph-level statistics for netify objects ‚Äî summary.netify
code: # S3 method for class 'netify' summary(object, ...)

title: Calculate graph-level statistics for netify objects ‚Äî summary.netify
text: object netify object containing network data ... Additional arguments, including: other_stats Named list custom functions calculate additional graph-level statistics. function accept matrix return named vector scalar values.

title: Calculate graph-level statistics for netify objects ‚Äî summary.netify
text: data frame one row per network/time period containing: Basic network properties: net Network/time identifier layer Layer name (multilayer networks) num_actors Number actors (num_row_actors num_col_actors bipartite networks) density Proportion possible ties exist num_edges Total number edges (unweighted count) prop_edges_missing Proportion potential edges NA weighted networks : mean_edge_weight Average weight existing edges sd_edge_weight Standard deviation edge weights median_edge_weight Median edge weight min_edge_weight, max_edge_weight Range edge weights Structural measures: competition (competition_row/competition_col) Herfindahl-Hirschman Index measuring concentration ties. Calculated \(\sum_{=1}^{n} (s_i)^2\) \(s_i\) actor 's share total ties. Ranges 1/n (equal distribution) 1 (one actor ties). sd_of_actor_means (sd_of_row_means/sd_of_col_means) Standard deviation actors' average tie strengths, measuring heterogeneity actor activity levels transitivity Global clustering coefficient (probability two neighbors node connected) directed networks : covar_of_row_col_means Covariance actors' sending receiving patterns reciprocity Correlation adjacency matrix transpose, measuring tendency mutual ties

title: Calculate graph-level statistics for netify objects ‚Äî summary.netify
text: function automatically adapts calculations based network properties: Bipartite networks: Reports row column actors separately Directed networks: Calculates separate statistics /ties Weighted networks: Includes weight-based statistics Multilayer networks: Processes layer independently Longitudinal networks: Calculates statistics time period Competition Index Interpretation: competition measure (HHI) captures concentrated network ties among actors. Low values indicate distributed activity across many actors (competitive), high values indicate concentration among actors (monopolistic). particularly useful analyzing power dynamics resource distribution networks. Custom Statistics: Add custom graph-level metrics using other_stats parameter:
code: # Example: Community detection modularity_stat <- function(mat) {   g <- netify_to_igraph(mat)   comm <- igraph::cluster_walktrap(g)   c(modularity = igraph::modularity(comm),     n_communities = length(unique(comm$membership))) }  summary(net, other_stats = list(community = modularity_stat))

title: Calculate graph-level statistics for netify objects ‚Äî summary.netify
text: large longitudinal multilayer networks, computation can intensive. Consider using subset_netify analyze specific time periods layers. Missing edges (NA values) excluded density calculations tracked prop_edges_missing statistic.

title: Calculate actor-level network statistics ‚Äî summary_actor
text: Computes comprehensive actor-level statistics netify objects, including degree, strength, centrality measures, custom metrics. Handles different network types (directed/undirected, weighted/unweighted) appropriately.

title: Calculate actor-level network statistics ‚Äî summary_actor
code: summary_actor(netlet, invert_weights_for_igraph = TRUE, other_stats = NULL)

title: Calculate actor-level network statistics ‚Äî summary_actor
text: netlet netify object containing network data invert_weights_for_igraph Logical. TRUE (default), inverts edge weights calculating closeness betweenness centrality, igraph interprets weights distances. Set FALSE weights already represent distances. other_stats Optional named list custom functions calculate additional actor-level statistics. function accept matrix return vector one value per actor.

title: Calculate actor-level network statistics ‚Äî summary_actor
text: data frame actor-level statistics. Columns always include: actor Actor name/identifier time Time period (longitudinal networks) layer Layer name (multilayer networks) Additional columns depend network type: undirected networks: degree Number connections. Calculated \(d_i = \sum_{j=1}^{n} a_{ij}\), \(a_{ij}\) adjacency matrix element. prop_ties Proportion possible ties realized. Calculated \(p_i = \frac{d_i}{n-1}\), \(d_i\) degree \(n\) total number actors. net_share Actor's share total network connections. Calculated \(s_i = \frac{d_i}{\sum_{j=1}^{n} d_j}\). closeness Closeness centrality. Calculated \(C_i = \frac{1}{\sum_{j} d(, j)}\), \(d(, j)\) shortest path distance every actor \(j\). betweenness Betweenness centrality. Calculated \(B_i = \sum_{s \neq \neq t} \frac{\sigma_{st}()}{\sigma_{st}}\), \(\sigma_{st}\) total number shortest paths node \(s\) node \(t\) \(\sigma_{st}()\) number paths pass \(\). eigen_centrality Eigenvector centrality, based principal eigenvector adjacency matrix. directed networks: in_degree, out_degree Incoming outgoing connections. \(d_i^{} = \sum_{j=1}^{n} a_{ji}\) \(d_i^{} = \sum_{j=1}^{n} a_{ij}\). in_prop_ties, out_prop_ties Proportion possible /ties total_degree Sum degree in_closeness, out_closeness Directed closeness centrality betweenness Betweenness centrality authority, hub Authority hub scores (asymmetric ) weighted networks, additional columns: strength_sum Sum edge weights. undirected: \(s_i^{sum} = \sum_{j=1}^{n} w_{ij}\). directed: separate /sums. strength_avg Average edge weight. Calculated \(s_i^{avg} = \frac{s_i^{sum}}{d_i}\). strength_sd Standard deviation edge weights. Calculated \(s_i^{sd} = \sqrt{\frac{1}{d_i} \sum_{j=1}^{n} (w_{ij} - s_i^{avg})^2}\). strength_median Median edge weight

title: Calculate actor-level network statistics ‚Äî summary_actor
text: function automatically adapts calculations based network properties: Centrality Measures: Degree: Count direct connections. directed networks, calculated separately incoming (-degree) outgoing (-degree) ties. Closeness: Measures quickly actor can reach others. Based inverse sum shortest path distances. Betweenness: Measures often actor lies shortest paths actors, indicating brokerage potential. Eigenvector: Measures importance based connections important actors. Computed using principal eigenvector adjacency matrix. Authority/Hub: directed networks . Authority scores measure importance targets ties important sources. Hub scores measure importance sources ties important targets. Weight Handling: default, function assumes larger weights indicate stronger relationships. calculating closeness betweenness centrality, weights inverted (1/weight) igraph treats edge weights distances. distance-based networks larger values already represent distances weaker relationships, set invert_weights_for_igraph = FALSE. Custom Statistics: Add custom metrics using other_stats parameter. function receives adjacency matrix return vector one value per actor: Mathematical Formulations: symmetric unweighted networks: Degree: \(d_i = \sum_{j=1}^{n} a_{ij}\) Proportion ties: \(p_i = \frac{d_i}{n-1}\) Network share: \(s_i = \frac{d_i}{\sum_{j=1}^{n} d_j}\) Closeness: \(C_i = \frac{1}{\sum_{j} d(, j)}\) Betweenness: \(B_i = \sum_{s \neq \neq t} \frac{\sigma_{st}()}{\sigma_{st}}\) symmetric weighted networks, additional measures: Strength sum: \(s_i^{sum} = \sum_{j=1}^{n} w_{ij}\) Strength average: \(s_i^{avg} = \frac{s_i^{sum}}{d_i}\) Strength standard deviation: \(s_i^{sd} = \sqrt{\frac{1}{d_i} \sum_{j=1}^{n} (w_{ij} - s_i^{avg})^2}\) asymmetric networks, statistics calculated separately rows () columns (), totals applicable.
code: # Example: Maximum tie weight for each actor max_out <- function(mat) apply(mat, 1, max, na.rm = TRUE) max_in <- function(mat) apply(mat, 2, max, na.rm = TRUE)  stats <- summary_actor(net,   other_stats = list(max_out = max_out, max_in = max_in))

title: Calculate actor-level network statistics ‚Äî summary_actor
text: longitudinal networks, statistics calculated separately time period. multilayer networks, statistics calculated separately layer unless layers aggregated beforehand. Missing values (NA) network excluded calculations. Isolates (actors connections) receive appropriate values (0 degree, NA centrality measures). function handles cross-sectional longitudinal data structures, well single-layer multilayer networks. ego networks created netify, function appropriately handles ego-alter structure.

title: Calculate actor-level network statistics ‚Äî summary_actor
text: Cassy Dorff, Shahryar Minhas

code: to_netify(net_obj, weight = NULL, ...)

title: Convert igraph, network, or matrix objects to netify format ‚Äî to_netify

Important specify igraph network objects default weight. ... Additional arguments passed new_netify. Can include nodal_data dyad_data override extracted attributes.

title: Convert igraph, network, or matrix objects to netify format ‚Äî to_netify
text: netify object : Adjacency matrix list matrices Nodal attributes (present input) Dyadic attributes (present input) Weight specification (provided)

title: Convert igraph, network, or matrix objects to netify format ‚Äî to_netify
text: function handles different input types: igraph: Extracts adjacency matrix, vertex attributes nodal data, edge attributes dyadic data network: Extracts adjacency matrix, vertex attributes nodal data, edge attributes dyadic data matrix: Direct conversion, attribute extraction array: Assumes 3D arrays represent longitudinal networks list: Must contain objects type (igraph, network, matrices) longitudinal data (lists 3D arrays), function creates netify object time-indexed components. Actor ordering preserved input objects made consistent across components (adjacency, nodal, dyadic data).

title: Convert igraph, network, or matrix objects to netify format ‚Äî to_netify
text: converting igraph network objects, specify weight parameter designate edge attribute used primary edge weight netify object.

title: Convert igraph, network, or matrix objects to netify format ‚Äî to_netify
text: Cassy Dorff, Shahryar Minhas

title: Convert igraph, network, or matrix objects to netify format ‚Äî to_netify
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # From igraph library(igraph) g <- sample_gnp(10, 0.3) E(g)$weight <- runif(ecount(g)) V(g)$type <- sample(c("A", "B"), vcount(g), replace = TRUE)  net <- to_netify(g, weight = "weight")  # From network library(network) n <- network(rgraph(10, tprob = 0.3)) set.vertex.attribute(n, "group", sample(1:2, 10, replace = TRUE))  net <- to_netify(n)  # From matrix adj_mat <- matrix(rnorm(100), 10, 10) net <- to_netify(adj_mat)  # From list of matrices (longitudinal) mat_list <- list(     "2001" = matrix(rnorm(100), 10, 10),     "2002" = matrix(rnorm(100), 10, 10) ) net <- to_netify(mat_list) } # }

what: Convert netify objects back to dyadic data frames ‚Äî unnetify
title: Convert netify objects back to dyadic data frames ‚Äî unnetify
text: unnetify (also available netify_to_df) reverses netify transformation converting network objects back dyadic (edge-level) data frames. function combines network structure associated nodal dyadic attributes, creating data frame row represents dyad (edge) relevant attributes attached.

title: Convert netify objects back to dyadic data frames ‚Äî unnetify
code: unnetify(netlet, remove_zeros = FALSE)  netify_to_df(netlet, remove_zeros = FALSE)

title: Convert netify objects back to dyadic data frames ‚Äî unnetify
text: netlet netify object converted dyadic format. remove_zeros Logical. TRUE, removes dyads zero edge weights output, resulting data frame non-zero relationships. FALSE (default), includes possible dyads network.

title: Convert netify objects back to dyadic data frames ‚Äî unnetify
text: data frame one row per dyad containing: : Name/ID first actor dyad : Name/ID second actor dyad time: Time period (longitudinal networks) weight column: Edge weight values (column named weight parameter used netify) from_id: Unique identifier combining actor time (longitudinal ) to_id: Unique identifier combining actor time (longitudinal ) Dyadic attributes: edge-level covariates original data Nodal attributes: Actor-level covariates merged onto dyads: directed networks: suffixed "_from" "_to" undirected networks: suffixed "_dyad"

title: Convert netify objects back to dyadic data frames ‚Äî unnetify
text: function essentially reverses netify process, making useful : Exporting network data analysis software Creating dyadic datasets regression analysis Inspecting network data familiar data frame format Merging network results back dyadic covariates directed networks, nodal attributes attached twice - sender (suffixed "_from") receiver (suffixed "_to"). allows modeling sender receiver effects separately. undirected networks, nodal attributes attached per dyad suffix "_dyad", since meaningful distinction sender receiver. function handles cross-sectional longitudinal netify objects, automatically detecting structure adjusting output accordingly.

title: Convert netify objects back to dyadic data frames ‚Äî unnetify
text: large networks, setting remove_zeros = FALSE can result large data frames, includes possible dyads (n √ó (n-1) directed networks n √ó (n-1) / 2 undirected networks).

title: Convert netify objects back to dyadic data frames ‚Äî unnetify
text: Cassy Dorff, Shahryar Minhas

title: Convert netify objects back to dyadic data frames ‚Äî unnetify
code: # Load example data data(icews)  # Create a netify object with attributes icews_10 <- icews[icews$year == 2010, ]  verbCoop_net <- netify(     icews_10,     actor1 = "i", actor2 = "j",     symmetric = FALSE,     weight = "verbCoop",     nodal_vars = c("i_polity2", "i_log_gdp"),     dyad_vars = c("verbConf", "matlConf") )  # Convert back to dyadic data frame dyad_df <- unnetify(verbCoop_net)  # Examine structure head(dyad_df) #>          from        to time verbCoop verbConf matlConf       from_id #> 1 Afghanistan   Albania    1        0        0        2 Afghanistan_1 #> 2 Afghanistan   Algeria    1        0        0        1 Afghanistan_1 #> 3 Afghanistan    Angola    1        0        0        0 Afghanistan_1 #> 4 Afghanistan Argentina    1        1        0        0 Afghanistan_1 #> 5 Afghanistan   Armenia    1        7        0        0 Afghanistan_1 #> 6 Afghanistan Australia    1      125        2       24 Afghanistan_1 #>         to_id i_polity2_from i_polity2_to i_log_gdp_from i_log_gdp_to #> 1   Albania_1             NA            9       23.49884     23.06701 #> 2   Algeria_1             NA            2       23.49884     25.67186 #> 3    Angola_1             NA           -2       23.49884     24.97089 #> 4 Argentina_1             NA            8       23.49884     27.03815 #> 5   Armenia_1             NA            5       23.49884     22.86492 #> 6 Australia_1             NA           10       23.49884     27.79745 names(dyad_df) #>  [1] "from"           "to"             "time"           "verbCoop"       #>  [5] "verbConf"       "matlConf"       "from_id"        "to_id"          #>  [9] "i_polity2_from" "i_polity2_to"   "i_log_gdp_from" "i_log_gdp_to"    # Remove zero-weight dyads for more compact output dyad_df_nonzero <- unnetify(verbCoop_net, remove_zeros = TRUE) nrow(dyad_df_nonzero) # Much smaller than full dyadic dataset #> [1] 9976  # Note how nodal attributes are added # For directed network: _from and _to suffixes head(dyad_df[, c("from", "to", "i_polity2_from", "i_polity2_to")]) #>          from        to i_polity2_from i_polity2_to #> 1 Afghanistan   Albania             NA            9 #> 2 Afghanistan   Algeria             NA            2 #> 3 Afghanistan    Angola             NA           -2 #> 4 Afghanistan Argentina             NA            8 #> 5 Afghanistan   Armenia             NA            5 #> 6 Afghanistan Australia             NA           10  # Longitudinal example verbCoop_longit <- netify(     icews,     actor1 = "i", actor2 = "j",     time = "year",     symmetric = FALSE,     weight = "verbCoop",     nodal_vars = c("i_polity2", "i_log_gdp") )  # Convert longitudinal network dyad_df_longit <- unnetify(verbCoop_longit, remove_zeros = TRUE)  # Check time periods are included table(dyad_df_longit$time) #>  #> 2002 2003 2004 2005 2006 2007 2008 2009 2010 2011 2012 2013 2014  #> 8692 8887 9514 9346 9429 9739 9988 9854 9976 9708 9841 9911 9774   # Each dyad now has associated time period # Note: weight column is named after the weight variable (verbCoop) head(dyad_df_longit[, c("from", "to", "time", "verbCoop")]) #>          from         to time verbCoop #> 1 Afghanistan    Albania 2002        6 #> 2 Afghanistan    Armenia 2002        3 #> 3 Afghanistan  Australia 2002       81 #> 4 Afghanistan    Austria 2002       17 #> 5 Afghanistan Azerbaijan 2002       14 #> 6 Afghanistan    Bahrain 2002       10  # Use the output for further analysis if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # For example, regression analysis lm(verbCoop ~ i_polity2_from + i_polity2_to + verbConf, data = dyad_df) } # }
